results.headline: Stolen Laughs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How to Rob a Bank

results.summary_short: The tedious little movie “How to Rob a Bank” would like to be a leaner, meaner example of the caper genre it also wants to send up.

results.headline: In a Red Hood and Running From the Wolves of London

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of London To Brighton

results.summary_short: With its jerky camerawork and gritty texture, the British film “London to Brighton” tries awfully hard to pass itself off as a slab of rancid naturalism.

results.headline: Southern Discomfort for a Hollywood Talk-Show Host

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Welcome Home Roscoe Jenkins

results.summary_short: “Roscoe Jenkins” is just a shaggy diversion that gives its energetic star and its populous, accomplished supporting cast a chance to clown around.

results.headline: What You See, What You Get

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hottie and the Nottie

results.summary_short: One would think that after increasingly embarrassing forays into reality television, the Internet and the penitentiary, Paris Hilton might have taken a moment to reflect on her choices. Or perhaps not.

results.headline: Tropical Pursuit of Love, Coins and No Tan Lines

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fool's Gold

results.summary_short: In “Fool’s Gold” Kate Hudson and Matthew McConaughey, as golden as a pair of rotisserie chickens, squabble and cavort in a tropical paradise.

results.headline: Hit Men on Holiday Get All Medieval

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Bruges

results.summary_short: In “In Bruges,” Brendan Gleeson, Colin Farrell and Ralph Fiennes have great fun rummaging around inside Martin McDonagh’s modest bag of tricks.

results.headline: Attention, Slackers: It’s a Jungle Out There

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Strange Wilderness

results.summary_short: Underachieving even by the standards of stoner comedies, “Strange Wilderness” is so inert that it doesn’t so much unreel on screen as loiter there.

results.headline: It’s Enough to Make Anyone Blink

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Eye

results.summary_short: “The Eye” is the latest Western deconstruction of a successful Asian horror movie and it is louder and more literal than its inspiration.

results.headline: Mehdi and Sarah and Adrien and Manu, Coupling Under a Cloud

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Witnesses

results.summary_short: The beautifully acted ensemble film “The Witnesses” sidesteps most of its opportunities for high drama, political sermonizing and the jerking of tears.

results.headline: An Obsessive Love of Prayer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Praying With Lior

results.summary_short: “Praying With Lior” documents the extraordinary life of Lior Liebling, a rabbi’s son with Down syndrome.

results.headline: Spreading Joy With a Mobile Disco
results.display_title: Build a Ship, Sail to Sadness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Build a Ship, Sail to Sadness

results.summary_short: “Build a Ship, Sail to Sadness” is a deliberate affront to the very idea of slick entertainment and is all the funnier as a result.

results.headline: A Haircut, With an Affair and Highlights of Support

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Caramel

results.summary_short: In the Beirut beauty salon where most of “Caramel” takes place, women of various shapes, sizes, ages and backgrounds gather to bond and gossip.

results.headline: Digging for Truth in a Life That’s Built Upon a Lie

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Live and Become

results.summary_short: Fundamental issues of ethnic and religious identity and the agony of exile are at the heart of “Live and Become.”

results.headline: Pop in 3-D
results.display_title: Hannah Montana & Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannah Montana & Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert

results.summary_short: “Hannah Montana and Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert” is a diverting 3-D artifact of Ms. Cyrus’s just concluded tour.

results.headline: A Guy, His Psychic and a Jealous Ghost

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Over Her Dead Body

results.summary_short: For what it is — a romantic comedy about the rivalry between a jealous ghost and a flaky psychic for the love of a veterinarian — “Over Her Dead Body” is not bad.

results.headline: It All Comes Down to (or Looks Up to) Bach

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Silence Before Bach

results.summary_short: The jingling piano, the humming traffic and the prancing horse tap out separate if connecting songs in the beguiling nonnarrative film “The Silence Before Bach.”

results.headline: Doing Battle on the Field of Parody

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Meet the Spartans

results.summary_short: Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, the team behind “Meet the Spartans,” prove that ridiculing other movies is much easier than making your own.

results.headline: A Spiritual Fight

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Orthodox Stance

results.summary_short: In the intriguingly layered documentary “Orthodox Stance,” a determined young boxer strives to prove that the laws of God and the laws of the ring need not be at odds.

results.headline: Friend Indeed Who Doesn’t Judge or Flinch

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days

results.summary_short: In “4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days,” a ferocious, unsentimental, often brilliantly directed film, the camera doesn’t follow the action, it expresses consciousness itself.

results.headline: An Overabundance of Hormones

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alice's House

results.summary_short: Chico Teixeira’s languid, libidinous “Alice’s House” is the best argument against marriage and motherhood to appear in many a year.
